com.alvermont.terraj.stargen
Class Enviro

java.lang.Object
  com.alvermont.terraj.stargen.Enviro

public class Enviro
extends java.lang.Object

Planetary environment related calculations and similar functions. Note that most of the comments in this class on the derivation of equations and other source material are taken directly from the original C code.

Version:
$Id: Enviro.java,v 1.19 2006/07/06 06:58:33 martin Exp $
Author:
martin

Method Detail

getDayLength

public double getDayLength(Planet planet)
Fogg's information for this routine came from Dole "Habitable Planets for Man", Blaisdell Publishing Company, NY, 1964. From this, he came up with his eq.12, which is the equation for the 'baseAngularVelocity' below. He then used an equation for the change in angular velocity per time (dw/dt) from P. Goldreich and S. Soter's paper "Q in the Solar System" in Icarus, vol 5, pp.375-389 (1966). Using as a comparison the change in angular velocity for the Earth, Fogg has come up with an approximation for our new planet (his eq.13) and take that into account. This is used to find 'changeInAngularVelocity' below. Input parameters are mass (in solar masses), radius (in Km), orbital period (in days), orbital radius (in AU), density (in g/cc), eccentricity, and whether it is a gas giant or not.

Parameters:
planet - The planet to calculate the day length for
Returns:
The length of the day in units of hours.

getInclination

public int getInclination(double orbRadius)
Calculate an inclination. The orbital radius is expected in units of Astronomical Units (AU). Inclination is returned in units of degrees.

Parameters:
orbRadius - The orbital radius in AU
Returns:
The inclination of the orbit in degrees

getEscapeVelocity

public double getEscapeVelocity(double mass,
                                double radius)
Calculate a planetary escape velocity. This function implements the escape velocity calculation. Note that it appears that Fogg's eq.15 is incorrect. The mass is in units of solar mass, the radius in kilometers, and the velocity returned is in cm/sec.

Parameters:
mass - The planetary mass in Solar masses
radius - The radius of the planet in KM
Returns:
The escape velocity in centimetres per second

getMoleculeLimit

public double getMoleculeLimit(double mass,
                               double equatRadius,
                               double exosphericTemp)
This function returns the smallest molecular weight retained by the body, which is useful for determining the atmosphere composition. Mass is in units of solar masses, and equatorial radius is in units of kilometers.

Parameters:
mass - The mass of the body in Solar masses
equatRadius - The equatorial radius of the body in KM
exosphericTemp - The temperateure of the body in degrees Kelvin
Returns:
The smallest retained molecular weight

getAcceleration

public double getAcceleration(double mass,
                              double radius)
This function calculates the surface acceleration of a planet. The mass is in units of solar masses, the radius in terms of km, and the acceleration is returned in units of cmsec2.

Parameters:
mass - The mass in solar masses
radius - The radius of the planet in kilometres
Returns:
The surface acceleration of the planet in centimetres per second squared

getGravity

public double getGravity(double acceleration)
This function calculates the surface gravity of a planet. The acceleration is in units of cm/sec2, and the gravity is returned in units of Earth gravities.

Parameters:
acceleration - The acceleration in units of centimeters per second squared
Returns:
The surface gravity as a multiple of Earth gratity

getVolInventory

public double getVolInventory(double mass,
                              double escapeVel,
                              double rmsVel,
                              double stellarMass,
                              int zone,
                              boolean greenhouseEffect,
                              boolean accretedGas)
This implements Fogg's eq.17. The 'inventory' returned is unitless.

Parameters:
mass - The planetary mass in Solar masses
escapeVel - The planetary escape velocity in centimeters per second
rmsVel - The rms velocity
stellarMass - The mass of the primary in Solar masses
zone - The orbital zone of the planet
greenhouseEffect - Indicates whether there is a greenhouse effect
accretedGas - Indicates whether gas has been accreted
Returns:
The volume inventory

getHydroFraction

public double getHydroFraction(double volatileGasInventory,
                               double planetRadius)
This function is Fogg's eq.22. Given the volatile gas inventory and planetary radius of a planet (in Km), this function returns the fraction of the planet covered with water. I have changed the function very slightly: the fraction of Earth's surface covered by water is 71%, not 75% as Fogg used.

Parameters:
volatileGasInventory - The volatile gas inventory of the planet
planetRadius - The planetary radius in kilometres
Returns:
The fraction of the planet covered by water

getCloudFraction

public double getCloudFraction(double surfTemp,
                               double smallestMWRetained,
                               double equatRadius,
                               double hydroFraction)
Given the surface temperature of a planet (in Kelvin), this function returns the fraction of cloud cover available. This is Fogg's eq.23. See Hart in "Icarus" (vol 33, pp23 - 39, 1978) for an explanation. This equation is Hart's eq.3. I have modified it slightly using constants and relationships from Glass's book "Introduction to Planetary Geology", p.46. The 'CLOUD_COVERAGE_FACTOR' is the amount of surface area on Earth covered by one Kg. of cloud.

Parameters:
surfTemp - The surface temperature in degrees Kelvin
smallestMWRetained - The smallest molecular weight retained
equatRadius - The equatorial radius of the planet in kilmetres
hydroFraction - The water fraction of the planet
Returns:
The cloud cover fraction for the planet

getIceFraction

public double getIceFraction(double hydroFraction,
                             double surfTemp)
Given the surface temperature of a planet (in Kelvin), this function returns the fraction of the planet's surface covered by ice. This is Fogg's eq.24. See Hart[24] in Icarus vol.33, p.28 for an explanation. I have changed a constant from 70 to 90 in order to bring it more in line with the fraction of the Earth's surface covered with ice, which is approximatly .016 (=1.6%).

Parameters:
hydroFraction - The water fraction of the planet
surfTemp - The surface temperature of the planet in degrees kelvin
Returns:
The ice fraction for the planet

getEffTemp

public double getEffTemp(double ecosphereRadius,
                         double orbRadius,
                         double albedo)
This is Fogg's eq.19. The ecosphere radius is given in AU, the orbital radius in AU, and the temperature returned is in Kelvin.

Parameters:
ecosphereRadius - The radius of the ecosphere in AU
orbRadius - The orbital radius in AU
albedo - The albedo of the planet
Returns:
The effective temperature in degrees Kelvin

getEstTemp

public double getEstTemp(double ecosphereRadius,
                         double orbRadius,
                         double albedo)
Get the surface temperature for a planet

Parameters:
ecosphereRadius - The radius of the ecosphere in AU
orbRadius - The orbital radius of the planet in AU
albedo - The albedo of the planet
Returns:
The surface temperature of the planet

isGreenhouse

public boolean isGreenhouse(double rEcosphere,
                            double orbRadius)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------- Old grnhouse: Note that if the orbital radius of the planet is greater than or equal to R_inner, 99% of it's volatiles are assumed to have been deposited in surface reservoirs (otherwise, it suffers from the greenhouse effect). -------------------------------------------------------------------------- if ((orbRadius < r_greenhouse) && (zone == 1)) -------------------------------------------------------------------------- The new definition is based on the inital surface temperature and what state water is in. If it's too hot, the water will never condense out of the atmosphere, rain down and form an ocean. The albedo used here was chosen so that the boundary is about the same as the old method Neither zone, nor r_greenhouse are used in this version JLB --------------------------------------------------------------------------

Parameters:
rEcosphere - The radius of the ecosphere in AU
orbRadius - The orbital radius of the planet in AU
Returns:
true
if there is a greenhouse effect otherwise 
false

getGreenRise

public double getGreenRise(double opticalDepth,
                           double effectiveTemp,
                           double surfPressure)
This is Fogg's eq.20, and is also Hart's eq.20 in his "Evolution of Earth's Atmosphere" article. The effective temperature given is in units of Kelvin, as is the rise in temperature produced by the greenhouse effect, which is returned. I tuned this by changing a pow(x,.25) to pow(x,.4) to match Venus - JLB

Parameters:
opticalDepth - The optical depth of the planet (dimensionless)
effectiveTemp - The effective temperature of the planet in degrees Kelvin
surfPressure - The surface pressure
Returns:
The temperature rise produced by greenhouse effect in degrees Kelvin

getPlanetAlbedo

public double getPlanetAlbedo(double waterFraction,
                              double cloudFraction,
                              double iceFraction,
                              double surfPressure)
Calculate the albedo of a planet. The surface temperature passed in is in units of Kelvin. The cloud adjustment is the fraction of cloud cover obscuring each of the three major components of albedo that lie below the clouds.

Parameters:
waterFraction - The water fraction of the planet
cloudFraction - The cloud fraction of the planet
iceFraction - The ice fraction of the planet
surfPressure - The surface atmospheric pressure of the planet
Returns:
The albedo of the planet

getOpacity

public double getOpacity(double molecularWeight,
                         double surfPressure)
This function returns the dimensionless quantity of optical depth, which is useful in determining the amount of greenhouse effect on a planet.

Parameters:
molecularWeight - The retained molecular weight of the planet
surfPressure - The surface pressure of the planet
Returns:
The optical depth of the planet

getGasLife

public double getGasLife(double molecularWeight,
                         Planet planet)
Calculates the number of years it takes for 1/e of a gas to escape from a planet's atmosphere. Taken from Dole p. 34. He cites Jeans (1916) & Jones (1923)

Parameters:
molecularWeight - The retained molecular weight of the planet
planet - The planet to calculate for
Returns:
The gas life of the planet in years

getMinMolecWeight

public double getMinMolecWeight(Planet planet)
Get the minimum molecular weight for a planet

Parameters:
planet - The planet to calculate for
Returns:
The minimum molecular weight for the planet

calculateSurfaceTemp

public void calculateSurfaceTemp(Planet planet,
                                 boolean first,
                                 double lastWater,
                                 double lastClouds,
                                 double lastIce,
                                 double lastTemp,
                                 double lastAlbedo)
The temperature calculated is in degrees Kelvin. Quantities already known which are used in these calculations: planet->molec_weight planet->surf_pressure R_ecosphere planet->a planet->volatile_gas_inventory planet->radius planet->boil_point

Parameters:
planet - the planet to be calculated for
first - Whether this is the first iteration 
true
if so
lastWater - The last water fraction
lastClouds - The last cloud fraction
lastIce - The last ice fraction
lastTemp - The last temperature calculated
lastAlbedo - The last albedo calculated

iterateSurfaceTemp

public void iterateSurfaceTemp(Planet planet)
Carry out an iteration to work out the surface temperature of a planet. On return the corresponding values will be set in the planet record.

Parameters:
planet - The planet to calculate the temperature for

getInspiredPartialPressure

public double getInspiredPartialPressure(double surfPressure,
                                         double gasPressure)
Inspired partial pressure, taking into account humidification of the air in the nasal passage and throat This formula is on Dole's p. 14

Parameters:
surfPressure - The surface pressure of the planet
gasPressure - The gas pressure of the planet
Returns:
The inspired partial pressure of the planet

getBreathability

public Breathability getBreathability(Planet planet)
This function uses figures on the maximum inspired partial pressures of Oxygen, other atmospheric and traces gases as laid out on pages 15, 16 and 18 of Dole's Habitable Planets for Man to derive breathability of the planet's atmosphere. JLB

Parameters:
planet - The planet to calculate breathability for
Returns:
An evaluation of atmosphere breathability of this planet
